intro: Caraguata vanvolxemii, commonly known as the Van Volxemii caraguata, is a rare and striking plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils at high altitudes, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments. Its leaves are broad and hairy, providing a distinctive appearance, while its flowers range in color from white to pink. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
